Situation1: They are asked to take part in an important family event like a holiday celebration or trip.
Expectation2: Ensure client satisfaction and address any concerns or complaints professionally
Situation2: An easygoing regular politely asks for a tiny adjustment to their fringe.
Story: I glanced at my phone, the group chat with my stepfamily lighting up with messages about the holiday dinner tonight. My stepdad’s text was clear: “We really want you there. It means a lot to your mom.” I knew how important these family gatherings were, especially since I was still finding my place in this new family. But as I set my phone down, my next client, Mrs. Patel, settled into my chair. She smiled, her usual warmth making me relax a little. “Just a tiny trim on the fringe, if you don’t mind,” she said, touching her hair lightly. I checked the clock—if I hurried, I might just make it to dinner on time. But Mrs. Patel was particular about her hair, and I prided myself on never rushing a client, always making sure they left happy. My hands hovered over her hair, my mind torn between the expectation to be the reliable step-sibling and the professional hairdresser. The weight of both roles pressed on me, and I could feel my heart pounding as I tried to figure out what to do next.
